captions.text:
That&#39;s right, I&#39;ve got a Nintendo Switch 2 now 
and have consequently been elevated to a higher

status of humanity. Unlike you regular Switch 
1-using plebs, my Switch&#39;s box has a great big

two on it that I can cut out and repurpose as a 
dish hook. And there are also other benefits as

well. I can play advanced, top-of-the-range launch 
titles such as Mario Kart World, and... well,

Rome wasn&#39;t burnt in a day. Incidentally, I 
briefly browsed the store to see if anything

else could make a case for itself, and one of the 
first games I saw there was Hentai Girls. Now,

I&#39;m no prude. You don&#39;t want to know what 
my dick is currently in (here&#39;s a hint:

it&#39;s not underpants) nor am I fan of the kind 
of moral panicking twats who ran around flapping

their wrists at GTA San Andreas back in the 
day for acknowledging that vaginas exist, but

it seems a reasonable scenario that my kids might 
see Hentai Girls and want to know the deal with

the cutesy cartoon ladies, and then I&#39;ll have to 
explain to them the concept of paizuri, and that&#39;s

exactly the sort of thing I would expect twats to 
be making a fuss about. Maybe the twats are all

busy these days complaining about trans people 
in bathrooms and not going to military parades.

But anyway, let&#39;s be real, the Switch 2 is just 
the Switch again but more powerful, and that&#39;s

fine. That&#39;s all I fucking wanted. No fucking 
ARG 3D camera cup holder fleshlight attachment

pointless tech innovations for innovation&#39;s sake, 
just a digital store that can actually now load

faster than a third-party video streaming site on 
the international space station and controllers

that you don&#39;t have to fiddle into little slidey 
rails like you&#39;re doing up the zip fastener of a

really socially awkward robot. No, now they 
just eagerly clip right on and off—yes, sir;

no, sir; ready to go, sir; anything we can suck 
for you while we&#39;ve got your attention, sir? So,

that&#39;s good. I do wish they could make it possible 
to figure out which way round the thing goes into

the charging dock in less than two tries, but 
I guess you&#39;ve got to leave some innovation for

the Switch 3. And hell, USB ports still haven&#39;t 
figured that one out. But the proof of the pudding

is in the eating and optionally the custard, 
and the only thing that matters is games. Or,

at time of writing, game. Yes, I played 
a fair bit of Mario Kart World last week.

Never having been particularly warm on Mario Kart. 
I&#39;ve played it, obviously, but never understood

why I was no good at it until now, when I found a 
single screen of explanatory text. Wait, you get a

speed boost from ramping and drifting? Why didn&#39;t 
my hypercompetitive asshole nephew ever tell me

that, or did I just answer my own question? 
So, armed with that knowledge, I magically

started having fun with Mario Kart. Although I 
still had two lingering questions. Question 1:

80 fucking dollars? Question 2: Really? So, from 
the main menu, you can play Grand Prix mode,

wherein you race around several tracks trying to 
be first, or Knockout Tour mode, wherein you race

around several tracks trying to be first, but if 
you come last early on, you&#39;re not obliged to hang

around continuing to humiliate yourself. The usual 
Mario stable of playable characters is offered;

obviously, I started with ma boi Luigi, but after 
I unlocked Princess Daisy, I switched to playing

as her out of continued second-banana solidarity. 
And because of all the princesses, she&#39;s the only

one who seems to know what to do with her hands 
while celebrating a win. Rosalina looks like she&#39;s

auditioning to be the fucking windscreen wipers. 
You can also play the game as a cow, a crab, or

a bee if you happen to have the self-esteem of a 
chronically depressed reformed Nazi war criminal.

I completed all the races and rolled credits 
inside two hours, and yeah, I guess I was having

fun. I even played in a few online knockout tours 
thanks to that Nintendo online subscription I keep

forgetting to cancel, and now that I knew about 
the drifting and ramping thing was able to play

quite competitively—that is to say, generally keep 
up with the pack and occasionally be chosen by the

roulette wheel of destiny to be randomly blessed 
with a power-up with which to cheat a win. Fun,

yes, but about as fulfilling an achievement as 
successfully shooting an apple off my son&#39;s head

with an intercontinental ballistic missile, and I 
couldn&#39;t help wondering, &quot;Isn&#39;t this game supposed

to be open world? Isn&#39;t that what all the fuss was 
about, nay, the whole reason for the title?&quot; And

while wondering, I finally noticed that, tucked 
away in teeny-weeny text in a little corner of the

main menu, far, far away from all the big tempting 
buttons for Grand Prix and Online Play was a

little prompt saying, &quot;Oh, by the way, press X to 
go into free roam if that&#39;s your thing. I dunno,

I ain&#39;t judging.&quot; And that&#39;s where the entire open 
world mode was hiding. You can freely explore this

huge, expansive, seamless map, looking for 
hidden pickups and doing random challenges.

With a breathtakingly pointless &quot;minimap&quot; in 
the corner of the screen that&#39;s literally just

a second camera positioned slightly 
higher. But considering the huge,

seamless world is nothing less than the eponymous 
feature of Mario Kart Huge, Seamless World,

the game seems oddly embarrassed about it. 
Yes, there are special challenges scattered

about—mainly &quot;go through these rings within a 
time limit like you&#39;re late for work and had

nothing in the house for breakfast but half a 
bag of Funyuns&quot;—but there&#39;s no reward to speak

of and nothing that keeps track of which ones 
you&#39;ve completed. You can drive to all the tracks

that are featured in the main gameplay modes, but 
you can&#39;t initiate a race or a time trial there;

you&#39;ve got to go back to the main menu to 
do that. Otherwise, all you can do is drive

around them by yourself and, I dunno, roleplay 
as a government safety inspector. There&#39;s no

sense of progress or discovery; there&#39;s not even 
a little number that goes up if you pick up coins,

and it all gives me the same uncomfortable feeling 
one gets eating at a restaurant that&#39;s secretly

a mafia front business. Slurping your little 
bowl of microwaved spaghetti by yourself in

an empty dining hall with the chef and all the 
waiters standing around giving you the evil eye,

waiting for you to bugger off so they can finish 
putting all the cocaine in little plastic baggies.

I&#39;m sure there will be some who will now 
respond, &quot;Don&#39;t you understand? This is

Nintendo&#39;s genius! Just as they reinvented Zelda 
by stripping things down in Breath of the Wild,

this is them inviting you to take a step back, 
forget about petty things like progress and

missions and story and making number go up, and 
just live in the moment.&quot; Perhaps, but it&#39;s funny

how a Mario Kart game making a deliberate 
artistic statement on Zen and the inherent

beauty of essentialism is indistinguishable 
from a Mario Kart game that just bunged in an

open world and then couldn&#39;t be buggered to do 
anything with it. Or indeed, a Mario Kart that

had to have all its seams hastily stapled up so 
it could be chucked out to coincide with a new

console launch. And to return to my previous 
questions: 80 fucking bucks? Really? Not that

there&#39;s any objective measure of video game value; 
I mean, it&#39;ll certainly keep the kids distracted,

but for 80 bucks, I&#39;m gonna expect to get at 
least two weeks in the British Virgin Islands.
